title: 106_hr2651
content: The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999, also known as the Act, eliminates restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. It includes exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, changes in the definition of group practice, and delays in implementing ownership referral changes until final regulations are issued. Additionally, it excludes intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses, permits supervision of clinical laboratory services by independent contractor pathologists, and specifies the effective date of the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to clarify ownership or investment interests in entities. Conforming amendments are made to sections regarding ownership and compensation arrangement prohibitions, exceptions for publicly traded securities and mutual funds, and the removal of certain language in subsection (d). In subsection (d), paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) are redesignated as paragraphs (4), (5), and (6) respectively, and transferred after paragraph (3) of subsection (b). Subsection (e) is struck. In subsection (f), ownership, investment, and compensation are changed to ownership and investment, and certain language is removed. In subsection (h), paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) are struck. In subsection (h), paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) are removed, and rules for faculty are updated. SEC. 3. EXCEPTIONS TO OWNERSHIP REFERRAL PROHIBITIONS. Revisions to Exception for In-Office Ancillary Services include repealing the site-of-service requirement and defining general supervision for individuals providing services under a physician's responsibility. The text chunk discusses amendments to the regulations regarding physician ownership of group practices, ancillary services furnished personally or through group practice, and exceptions for services furnished in rural areas. The changes include clarifications on licensure requirements, treatment of physician owners, and the percentage of services required in rural areas. SEC. 4 amends the definition of group practice to include physicians as owners or employees. SEC. 5 delays the implementation of ownership referral changes until final regulations are issued. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to exclude intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses. SEC. 7 allows pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services for a group practice. SEC. 8 states that the amendments apply to referrals made after the enactment date of the Act.
